user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 2.1 is: A project shall not contain unreachable code.

</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_DeleteAllObjects:
```c
void OS_DeleteAllObjects(void)
{
    uint32 ObjectCount;
    uint32 TryCount;

    /*
     * Note - this is done in a loop because some objects depend on other objects
     * and you will not be able to delete the object until the ref count becomes zero.
     */
    TryCount = 0;
    while (true)
    {
        ObjectCount = 0;
        ++TryCount;

        /* Delete timers and tasks first, as they could be actively using other object types  */
        OS_ForEachObjectOfType(OS_OBJECT_TYPE_OS_TIMECB, OS_OBJECT_CREATOR_ANY, OS_CleanUpObject, &ObjectCount);
        OS_ForEachObjectOfType(OS_OBJECT_TYPE_OS_TIMEBASE, OS_OBJECT_CREATOR_ANY, OS_CleanUpObject, &ObjectCount);
        OS_ForEachObjectOfType(OS_OBJECT_TYPE_OS_TASK, OS_OBJECT_CREATOR_ANY, OS_CleanUpObject, &ObjectCount);

        /* Then try to delete all other remaining objects of any type */
        OS_ForEachObject(OS_OBJECT_CREATOR_ANY, OS_CleanUpObject, &ObjectCount);

        if (ObjectCount == 0 || TryCount > 4)
        {
            break;
        }
        OS_TaskDelay(5);
    }
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function OS_DeleteAllObjects:
void OS_ForEachObjectOfType(osal_objtype_t idtype, osal_id_t creator_id, OS_ArgCallback_t callback_ptr,
                            void *callback_arg)
{
    OS_object_iter_t    iter;
    OS_creator_filter_t filter;

    filter.creator_id    = creator_id;
    filter.user_callback = callback_ptr;
    filter.user_arg      = callback_arg;

    if (OS_ObjectIdIteratorInit(OS_ForEachFilterCreator, &filter, idtype, &iter) == OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        while (OS_ObjectIdIteratorGetNext(&iter))
        {
            OS_ObjectIdIteratorProcessEntry(&iter, OS_ForEachDoCallback);
        }

        OS_ObjectIdIteratorDestroy(&iter);
    }
}
...
void OS_ForEachObject(osal_id_t creator_id, OS_ArgCallback_t callback_ptr, void *callback_arg)
{
    osal_objtype_t idtype;

    for (idtype = 0; idtype < OS_OBJECT_TYPE_USER; ++idtype)
    {
        OS_ForEachObjectOfType(idtype, creator_id, callback_ptr, callback_arg);
    }
}
...
void OS_CleanUpObject(osal_id_t object_id, void *arg)
{
    uint32 *ObjectCount;

    ObjectCount = (uint32 *)arg;
    ++(*ObjectCount);
    switch (OS_IdentifyObject(object_id))
    {
        case OS_OBJECT_TYPE_OS_TASK:
            OS_TaskDelete(object_id);
            break;
        case OS_OBJECT_TYPE_OS_QUEUE:
            OS_QueueDelete(object_id);
            break;
        case OS_OBJECT_TYPE_OS_BINSEM:
            OS_BinSemDelete(object_id);
            break;
        case OS_OBJECT_TYPE_OS_COUNTSEM:
            OS_CountSemDelete(object_id);
            break;
        case OS_OBJECT_TYPE_OS_MUTEX:
            OS_MutSemDelete(object_id);
            break;
        case OS_OBJECT_TYPE_OS_MODULE:
            OS_ModuleUnload(object_id);
            break;
        case OS_OBJECT_TYPE_OS_TIMEBASE:
            OS_TimeBaseDelete(object_id);
            break;
        case OS_OBJECT_TYPE_OS_TIMECB:
            OS_TimerDelete(object_id);
            break;
        case OS_OBJECT_TYPE_OS_STREAM:
            OS_close(object_id);
            break;
        case OS_OBJECT_TYPE_OS_DIR:
            OS_DirectoryClose(object_id);
            break;
        case OS_OBJECT_TYPE_OS_CONDVAR:
            OS_CondVarDelete(object_id);
            break;
        default:
            break;
    }
}
...
int32 OS_TaskDelay(uint32 millisecond)
{
    /* just call the implementation */
    return OS_TaskDelay_Impl(millisecond);
}
...
#define OS_OBJECT_TYPE_OS_TIMECB 0x09
...
#define OS_OBJECT_TYPE_OS_TIMEBASE 0x08
...
#define OS_OBJECT_TYPE_OS_TASK 0x01
...
#define OS_OBJECT_CREATOR_ANY OS_OBJECT_ID_UNDEFINED
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: I selected the above fragments because they contain control-flow structures and call sites where code could be (or appear to be) unreachable depending on configuration, constants, or iterator behavior. Specific reasons to investigate these areas: - The while(true) loop in OS_DeleteAllObjects and its break condition depend on TryCount, ObjectCount, and the behavior of called functions; this can create either infinite-loop scenarios or code paths that never execute parts of the loop. - The calls to OS_ForEachObjectOfType / OS_ForEachObject are responsible for driving deletion; if the iterator initialization/next functions never succeed for some idtype ranges or if OS_OBJECT_TYPE_USER is zero/incorrect, the inner bodies may never execute. - The for-loop in OS_ForEachObject uses OS_OBJECT_TYPE_USER as an upper bound; if that macro value is zero or incorrect, the loop body becomes unreachable. - The iterator pattern in OS_ForEachObjectOfType (if-init then while-get-next) can make the while body unreachable when Init succeeds but GetNext immediately fails, or the entire block unreachable if Init never returns OS_SUCCESS. - The switch in OS_CleanUpObject enumerates many object-type cases; some cases might never be reachable if OS_IdentifyObject cannot return those values, or conversely the default branch may be unreachable. Other smaller fragments (variable declarations, simple wrappers such as OS_TaskDelay returning OS_TaskDelay_Impl, macro definitions for individual object-type constants) were not included because they do not by themselves introduce unreachable code: they are declarations or trivial passthroughs without divergent control flow. Likewise, simple increments (++TryCount, ++(*ObjectCount)), assignments, and the break statement inside the switch are normal control-flow constructs whose reachability depends on the higher-level items already flagged above; they do not on their own indicate unreachable code that needs separate investigation.
